```{r}
b<-read.csv("matrix.csv")

head(b)
a<-as.matrix(b[1:429,2:7])
A<-t(a)%*%a
A
eigen(A)
```

```{r}
u1<-svd(A)$u[,1]/norm(svd(A)$u[,1],'2') #normalized dominate eigenvector
u2<-svd(A)$u[,2]/norm(svd(A)$u[,2], '2') #normalized second eigenvector
eigenvalues <- svd(A)$d
head(u1)
plot(u1,u2)
#text(u1, u2, label = '.')
```

```{r}
eigenvalues/sum(eigenvalues)
```
```{r}
v1 <- eigen(a%*%t(a))$vectors[,1]/norm(eigen(a%*%t(a))$vectors[,1],'2') #normalized v1
v2 <- eigen(a%*%t(a))$vectors[,2]/norm(eigen(a%*%t(a))$vectors[,2],'2') #normalized v2
```

In this case, we found that the dominant eigenvector accounts for over 78% of the voting matrix, the second vector account for over 13% of the voting matrix, along with the other eigenvectors that account for less than 5% of the matrix.

We can use the dominant and the second eigenvectors to approximate our voting matrix, which gives us:
```{r}
appro <- sqrt(eigen(A)$values[1]) * u1 %*% t(v1) + sqrt(eigen(A)$values[2]) * u2 %*% t(v2)
appro
```
